elements.content: Reaction of magnesium, calcium, strontium, and barium salts with a range of dicarboxylic acids [benzene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid (H2BDC), naphthalene-2,6-dicarboxylic acid (H2NDC), 4,5,9,10-tetrahydropyrene-2,7-dicarboxylic acid (H2TPDC), pyrene-2,7-dicarboxylic acid (H2PDC), 5,10-dihydroanthracene-2,7-dicarboxylic acid (H2DADC)] in N,N′-dimethylformamide (DMF) or N,N′-diethylformamide (DEF) in Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclaves produces a range of metal−organic framework materials. Single crystal X-ray analysis has confirmed that the predominant building block in these materials is a chain of metal centers bridged either by carboxylate moieties alone as in [M(DMF)(μ-BDC)]∞ (M = Mg or Sr), [Ca1.5(DEF)(μ-BDC)1.5]∞, and [Sr(DEF)(OH2)(μ-BDC)]∞ or bridged by both carboxylate ligands and DMF/DEF molecules as in [M(μ-DMF)(μ-NDC)]∞ (M = Ca, Sr, or Ba), [M(μ-DEF)(μ-TPDC)]∞ (M = Ca or Sr), [M(μ-DMF)(μ-DADC)]∞ (M = Ca or Sr), and [Sr(μ-DEF)(μ-PDC)]∞. In contrast, the isomorphous complexes [Mg3(DMF)4(μ-NDC)3]∞ and [Mg3(DEF)4(μ-NDC)3]∞ contain centrosymmetric trinuclear moieties in which each pair of cations is bridged by three carboxylate anions with two pendant solvent molecules coordinated to each of the terminal Mg2+ cations. These trinuclear building blocks act as six-connected nodes and generate a tilted α-Po type structure. Eleven of the 12 structures based upon cationic chains adopt a common extended architecture in which the aryldicarboxylate anions link the chains to generate diamond-shaped channels. However, in the material [Sr(DMF)(μ-BDC)]∞, the chains are linked to generate a hexagonal motif of triangular channels. In all 12 compounds based on cationic chains, the space within the channels is occupied by coordinated solvent molecules, leading to nonporous materials.

elements.content:
Metal−organic ligand framework materials have been prepared using diarylcarboxylates combined with magnesium, and, for the first time, with nonhydrated calcium, strontium, and barium centers.

Introduction

Metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) are molecular architectures comprising metal ion nodes bridged by organic ligands, which have attracted much interest recently due to their potential as porous hosts. Much research has centered on metal carboxylates, and in particular on cubic frameworks based upon [Zn4O]6+ nodes linked by linear aryldicarboxylates and related paddle-wheel complexes incorporating [M2(O2CR)4] units. The anionic nature of the carboxylate linker negates the need for counteranions in the framework, and this increases the potential for porosity in the framework products. These compounds can show high thermally stability and have rigid and extended structures that can reversibly adsorb small organic molecules. Furthermore, they have been shown to have significant potential as hydrogen sorption materials.
elements.clean_text:
Metal-organic ligand framework materials have been prepared using diarylcarboxylates combined with magnesium, and, for the first time, with nonhydrated calcium, strontium, and barium centers.

Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are molecular architectures comprising metal ion nodes bridged by organic ligands, which have attracted much interest recently due to their potential as porous hosts. Much research has centered on metal carboxylates, and in particular on cubic frameworks based upon [Zn4O]6+ nodes linked by linear aryldicarboxylates and related paddle-wheel complexes incorporating [M2(O2CR)4] units. The anionic nature of the carboxylate linker negates the need for counteranions in the framework, and this increases the potential for porosity in the framework products. These compounds can show high thermally stability and have rigid and extended structures that can reversibly adsorb small organic molecules. Furthermore, they have been shown to have significant potential as hydrogen sorption materials.

elements.content: In this work, a range of Group II metal cations of diverse size (Table ) have been used to investigate the effect of metal cation size on the structure and stability of extended structures of aryldicarboxylate-bridged metal organic frameworks. Due to its relatively low atomic mass (M r = 24.31), particular focus has been placed on the Mg2+ species since this is a good candidate metal ion for inclusion in hydrogen storage materials owing to the need for light materials to realize the U.S. Department of Energy storage target of 6.5 wt %. Multidentate carboxylate functionalities were chosen as they are known to chelate and lock metal ions in clusters, which act as rigid entities. Benzene-1,4-dicarboxylate (BDC2−), naphthalene-2,6-dicarboxylate (NDC2−), 4,5,9,10-tetrahydropyrene-2,7-dicarboxylate (TPDC2−), pyrene-2,7-dicarboxylate (PDC2−), and 5,10-dihydroanthracene-2,7-dicarboxylate (DADC2−) (Scheme ) were studied to assess the significance of (i) length and (ii) bulk of the linker on the architecture of the resultant framework. The C···C separation between the carboxylate carbon atoms of BDC2−, NDC2−, TPDC2−, PDC2−, and DADC2−, which have one, two, four, four, and three six-membered rings, is 5.81, 8.02, 10.05, 10.03, and 10.42 Å, respectively.

elements.content: A major impetus for this work is derived from the fact that previously reported examples of Group II aryldicarboxylate framework polymers are rare and restricted to only three examples with Mg2+  and sporadic examples of hydrated polymers of Ca2+, Sr2+, or Ba2+. Examples of porous frameworks with Al3+ have been described. Dincâ and Long reported the isolation of the first magnesium-based metal−organic framework, [Mg3(DEF)4(μ-NDC)3]∞ (DEF = diethylformamide), 1, which shows a neutral 3D framework in which linear [Mg3]6+ cationic units incorporating two terminal N,N′-diethylformamide (DEF) molecules at each end are linked by NDC2− anions. Following treatment at 190 °C under dynamic vacuum, its desolvated derivative was found to absorb virtually no N2 but limited quantities of O2 and H2 (0.46 wt % at 880 torr). Subsequently, Senkovska and Kaskel reported the analogous DMF-solvated species [Mg3(DMF)4(μ-NDC)3]∞ (DMF = N,N′-dimethylformamide), 2. Following treatment at 195 °C under vacuum, the desolvated derivative of 2 was found to absorb limited quantities of N2, O2, CH4, and H2 (0.78 wt % at 760 torr). Although 2 could be converted into 1, the reverse process was not realized. We were particularly interested in investigating frameworks with other Group II metal ions and report herein structural studies on a range of arylcarboxylate complexes of Mg2+, Ca2+, Sr2+, and Ba2+.

elements.content: All chemicals, except H2TPDC, H2PDC, and H2DADC, which were prepared following published procedures, were purchased from Aldrich Chemical Co Ltd. and used as received. Elemental analysis (CHN) was performed either by the Nottingham University School of Chemistry Microanalytical Service using a Perkin-Elmer 240B instrument or by Stephen Boyer at London Metropolitan University. Infrared spectra were obtained in the solid state using a Nicolet Avatar 3200 FTIR spectrometer. 1H NMR spectra were obtained by dissolution and breakup of the products in D2O and referenced to residual protio solvent using a Bruker DPX 300 spectrometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Details

All chemicals, except H2TPDC, H2PDC, and H2DADC, which were prepared following published procedures, were purchased from Aldrich Chemical Co Ltd. and used as received. Elemental analysis (CHN) was performed either by the Nottingham University School of Chemistry Microanalytical Service using a Perkin-Elmer 240B instrument or by Stephen Boyer at London Metropolitan University. Infrared spectra were obtained in the solid state using a Nicolet Avatar 3200 FTIR spectrometer. 1H NMR spectra were obtained by dissolution and breakup of the products in D2O and referenced to residual protio solvent using a Bruker DPX 300 spectrometer.

elements.content: Hydrated magnesium nitrate (128 mg, 0.50 mmol) and H2NDC (108 mg, 0.50 mmol) were dissolved in DEF (8 cm3) in a vial. The vial was placed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated to 130 °C for 5 days. This produced colorless block crystals of X-ray quality. Monoclinic, space group C2/c, a = 15.05, b = 18.04, c = 20.80 Å, β = 101.5°, V = 5578 Å3.

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction data were collected at 150 K using either Bruker SMART APEX (3, 8, 12, and 14) or Bruker SMART1000 (4–7, 9–11, and 13) CCD area detector diffractometers equipped with Oxford Cryosystems open flow cryostats. The radiation used was graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Pertinent details of crystal data, data collection, and processing are given in Table . The structures were solved by direct methods using SHELXS97 and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using SHELXL97. Following location in Fourier difference syntheses, aromatic and aliphatic hydrogen atoms were placed in geometrically calculated positions and refined thereafter using a riding model. In 8, the water H atom was found from the difference Fourier map and refined with restraints. All fully occupied nonhydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. In the case of disorder, all atoms were refined with isotropic displacement parameters, and the crystal structures were treated as described below:
elements.clean_text:
Crystallography

Single crystal X-ray diffraction data were collected at 150 K using either Bruker SMART APEX (3, 8, 12, and 14) or Bruker SMART1000 (4-7, 9-11, and 13) CCD area detector diffractometers equipped with Oxford Cryosystems open flow cryostats. The radiation used was graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Pertinent details of crystal data, data collection, and processing are given in Table . The structures were solved by direct methods using SHELXS97 and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using SHELXL97. Following location in Fourier difference syntheses, aromatic and aliphatic hydrogen atoms were placed in geometrically calculated positions and refined thereafter using a riding model. In 8, the water H atom was found from the difference Fourier map and refined with restraints. All fully occupied nonhydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. In the case of disorder, all atoms were refined with isotropic displacement parameters, and the crystal structures were treated as described below:

In 3, the DMF molecule containing N2 was modeled for disorder over two positions, with occupancy 58%:42%. In 5, the DEF molecule was modeled for disorder over two positions, occupancy 72%:28%. In this case, the hydrogen atoms on the solvent molecules were omitted from the model. In 6, the saturated ring of the pyrene was modeled for disorder at C4 and C8 over two positions, occupancy 50%:50%. Disorder was also modeled for the DEF molecule over two positions, occupancy 50%:50%. In 7, the DMF was modeled for disorder over two positions over a symmetry element, occupancy 50%:50%. In 8, the DEF was modeled for disorder over two positions, occupancy 50%:50%. In 11, atoms C22 and C23 of the DEF were modeled for disorder over two positions, occupancy 50%:50%. In 12, the carbon atoms of the DEF were modeled for disorder over two positions, occupancy 71%:29%. In 13, the DMF was modeled for disorder over a mirror plane, with two half−occupied orientations with the nitrogen atom lying in the mirror plane and common to both orientations. In 14, only the barium atom could be refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. O3 was modeled for disorder over two positions, occupancy 50%:50%. PLATON SQUEEZE was used to model areas of diffuse electron density, 1.5 molecules of DMF per cell, included in cell contents and all values calculated from them. Structural diagrams were produced using either XP (cationic centers) or OLEX (chains and extended views).

elements.content: Slow cooling of reaction mixtures comprising metal chloride or nitrate and aryldicarboxylic acid dissolved in dimethylformamide (DMF) or diethylformamide (DEF), previously heated to 100–150 °C for 5 days in autoclaves (1–3 and 5–13) or pressure tubes (4 and 14), yielded 12 hitherto unreported compounds, together with materials 1 and 2 which have been reported previously. The molecular formulae of, and the synthetic routes leading to, materials 1–14 are collected in Table . All of frameworks 1–14 have been identified unambiguously by single crystal X-ray diffraction methods. It is important to emphasize that these crystalline products were often formed as mixtures together with starting materials and/or other products, both amorphous and crystalline, such that single phase bulk materials could often not be isolated.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Slow cooling of reaction mixtures comprising metal chloride or nitrate and aryldicarboxylic acid dissolved in dimethylformamide (DMF) or diethylformamide (DEF), previously heated to 100-150 °C for 5 days in autoclaves (1-3 and 5-13) or pressure tubes (4 and 14), yielded 12 hitherto unreported compounds, together with materials 1  and 2  which have been reported previously. The molecular formulae of, and the synthetic routes leading to, materials 1-14 are collected in Table . All of frameworks 1-14 have been identified unambiguously by single crystal X-ray diffraction methods. It is important to emphasize that these crystalline products were often formed as mixtures together with starting materials and/or other products, both amorphous and crystalline, such that single phase bulk materials could often not be isolated.

The coordination geometries of the metal centers in 3–14 are shown in Figure together with those for 2, which are included for comparative purposes. Pertinent interatomic distances in 3–14 are collected in Table . All of the Mg2+ cations are 6-coordinate [Figure a−d], all of the Sr2+ and Ba2+ cations are 8-coordinate [Figure j−p], and the intermediate sized Ca2+ cations are 6-, 7-, or 8-coordinate [Figure e−i]. As would be expected, the length of the metal···oxygen (M···O) bond increases as the radius of the metal cation increases, with average M···O bond lengths of 2.08, 2.42, 2.60, and 2.79 Å for Mg2+, Ca2+, Sr2+, and Ba2+ compounds, respectively (Table ). The M···O bond also lengthens within the Ca frameworks as the coordination number increases from 6 to 8 with an average Ca···O bond length of 2.35, 2.39, and 2.45 Å for 6-, 7-, and 8-coordinate Ca2+, respectively (Table ).

The cationic building blocks in 3–14 are shown in Figure together with those for 2, which are included for comparison purposes. The metal cations are bridged by carboxylate ligands and, in some cases, by solvent molecules to form building blocks with either trinuclear as in 2 or polymeric metal−carboxylate chain motifs as in 3–14. In the latter complexes, the carboxylate moieties adopt a range of coordination modes in which they can bridge, chelate, or perform a combination of both, as illustrated in Scheme . The differing coordination of the metal cations by the carboxylate moieties can clearly be seen in Figure , which depicts the trinuclear cationic building block of 2 and typical examples, taken from 3, 4, 8, 9, and 11, of the polymeric cationic building blocks.

elements.content: In 1 and 2, the building block is a centrosymmetric trinuclear unit comprising three 6-coordinate Mg2+ cations bridged by NDC2− carboxylate moieties with two terminal dialkylformamide molecules at each end [Figure a]. The central Mg2+ ion (Mg2) has an almost perfect octahedral geometry provided by four type a carboxylate and two c1 carboxylate oxygen donors [Figure b]. The flanking magnesium cations (Mg1) are slightly distorted from octahedral, with each cation having two type a carboxylate, one c2, and one c3 carboxylate oxygen donors, with the coordination sphere completed by the oxygens of two terminal dialkylformamide molecules [Figure a].

The central Mg2+ ion (Mg2) has an almost perfect octahedral geometry provided by four type a carboxylate and two c1 carboxylate oxygen donors [Figure b]. The flanking magnesium cations (Mg1) are slightly distorted from octahedral, with each cation having two type a carboxylate, one c2, and one c3 carboxylate oxygen donors, with the coordination sphere completed by the oxygens of two terminal dialkylformamide molecules [Figure a].

elements.content: In 3 [Figure b], the building block is a chain of alternating centrosymmetric pairs of cations bridged by BDC2− carboxylate moieties with pendant solvent molecules bound to the metal cations. There are two crystallographically distinct 6-coordinate Mg2+ cations, which are slightly distorted from an octahedral geometry [Figure c and d]. Mg1 has two type a, two d2, and one d1 carboxylate oxygen donors, with the sixth site occupied by the oxygen of a pendant DMF molecule, while Mg2 has four type a and one d1 carboxylate oxygen donors, with the sixth site occupied by the oxygen of a pendant DMF molecule.

elements.content: In 4, the asymmetric unit comprises two crystallographically different Ca2+ cations, one on a center of inversion and one in a general position leading to a chain with a Ca(1)Ca(2)Ca(2) repetitive sequence [Figure c]. The cation on the center of inversion [Ca(1); Figure e] shows a distorted octahedral geometry provided by two type a, two c1, and two d1 carboxylate oxygen donors. The cation in a general position [Ca(2); Figure f] has distorted pentagonal biprismatic geometry provided by one type a, one c2, one c3, one d1, and two d2 carboxylate oxygen donors, with the seventh site occupied by the oxygen of a pendant DEF molecule.

elements.content: In 5–7 and 10–14, all of which have the same 1:1:1 metal cation:solvent:dicarboxylate anion stoichiometry and which adopt similar space groups (Pnma for 5–7 and 13; P212121 for 10–12 and 14), the building blocks consist of a chain of metal cations bridged by carboxylate moieties (NDC2− for 5, 10, and 14, TPDC2− for 6 and 11; PDC2− for 12, DADC2− for 7 and 13) and either DMF (5, 7, 10, 13, and 14) or DEF (6, 11, and 12) molecules [Figure f]. All metal cations are equivalent and 8-coordinated with a square antiprismatic geometry provided by two c1, two c2, and two c3 carboxylate oxygen donors, with the final two sites filled with the oxygens of bridging DMF/DEF molecules [Figures g−i and p)].

elements.content: In 8 and 9, the building block is a zigzag chain of Sr2+ cations bridged by BDC2− carboxylate moieties with pendant DMF (8) [Figure d] or DEF and H2O (9) [Figure e] molecules. In both 8 and 9, the Sr2+ cations are 8-coordinate with a distorted square antiprismatic geometry. In 8, each Sr2+ cation has one c1, one c2, one c3, two d1, and two d2 carboxylate oxygen donors, with the eighth site occupied by the oxygen of a pendant DMF molecule [Figure j]. In 9, each Sr2+ cation has two b, two d1, and two d2 carboxylate oxygen donors, while pendant DEF and water molecules provide the oxygens for the seventh and eighth coordination sites [Figure k].

elements.content: The different modes of coordination of the carboxylates observed in these structures are summarized in Table with pertinent interatomic distances and angles in Table . Mode a is common for low coordination number compounds but is not observed for 8-coordinate geometries. Mode b is only observed in the 8-coordinate strontium center in 9. Although only a very limited number of examples of modes c1, c2, and c3 are observed for 6-coordinate metal centers, they are quite common for 7- and 8-coordinate ones. Modes d1 and d2, although uncommon, are found for 6-, 7-, and 8-coordinate geometries and are comparable to modes c1 and c2. Whereas terminal solvent (DMF/DEF) molecules have been found in 6-, 7-, and 8-coordinate geometries, bridging solvent molecules occur exclusively in 8-coordinate metal centers. Not unexpectedly, as the coordination number of the metal center increases, the tendency for the ligating oxygen atom, from both carboxylate and solvent, to bridge two metal centers increases.

Inspection of the detailed geometrical parameters for the above metal–ligand interactions reveals some interesting trends. First, the M···O distances generally increase in length from mode a through mode c1/d1 and c3 to c2/d2 (Table ). Second, for all four cations, the cation and chelating carboxylate moiety ligating through modes c2/d2 and c3 exhibit near coplanarity, as quantified by the deviation of the cation from the carboxylate plane (Table ), but the cation often lies some distance from the carboxylate plane when ligated through modes a and c1/d1. Third, a similar differentiation applies to the <MOC bond angles; those for modes c2/d2 and c3 are close to 90°, while, those for mode a average between 131 and 137° and those for modes c1/d1 range up to 167.7°. Strong coordinate interactions between sp2-hybridized monodentate carboxylate oxygen atoms and the metal center should give rise to minimum deviations of the cation from the carboxylate plane and <MOC bond angles close to 120° (Scheme ). Increased deviations in <MOC bond angles will occur, however, when two metal centers are coordinated as in mode a, owing to the repulsive electrostatic forces between two closely located cationic centers. This is the case for both Mg2+ and Ca2+ coordination in these compounds (Table ). For bidentate chelating carboxylate moieties where four-membered MOCO rings are formed, the <MOC angles are restricted to much lower values, and for planar rings, they depend upon the bite angle formed by the chelating ligand, the average value of which decreases from 60 through 53 to 49° as the M···O distance increases from Mg2+, Ca2+, and Sr2+. Assuming an <OCO angle of 120°, the <MOC angles should increase from 90 through 93.5 to 95.5°. Hence, we consider the bidentate chelating c2/d2 and c3 contacts in these Mg2+, Ca2+, and Sr2+ compounds, which exhibit low deviations and average <MOC angles of 89.4, 92.6, and 93.1°, respectively, to be fairly strong coordinate interactions. Modes c1/d1, which do not have any restrictions similar to those described for modes a, c2/d2, and c3, have neither low deviations nor <MOC angles close to 120°. Hence, we consider them to be secondary interactions, which are less directed and more electrostatic in nature.

The Zn···O distance is dependent on both coordination mode, increasing from mode a (average Zn···O of 2.02 Å) through c1 (2.13 Å) to c2 (2.25 Å) and c3 (2.27 Å) and coordination number increasing from 4- (average Zn···O for mode a coordination, 1.93 Å) to 5- (1.94 Å) to 6-coordinate Zn2+ (2.02 Å). The average deviation from the plane of the carboxylate ligand for the bidentate chelating modes c2/c3 (0.18 Å) and for mode a (0.19 Å) in {[Zn3(1,4-BDC)3(DEF)2]·DEF}∞ is close to the theoretical ideal for a coordinate interaction (0.00 Å), while that for c1 (1.18 Å) is much larger suggesting the latter interaction to be less directional and hence more electrostatic. These conclusions are also supported by the average <MOC angles, which are restricted by the bidentate chelating modes to ca. 90° (c2 92°; c3 91°) but not by mode a or c1 for which the values (a 129°; c1 143°) are considerably larger than the theoretical ideal for a coordinate interaction (120°).

elements.content: When linked by the aryldicarboxylate anions, the linear cationic building blocks of 3–14 align parallel to one of the crystallographic axes (Tables and ) to create similar 3D architectures (Figure ). With the exception of 8, which has triangular channels [Figure b], the extended structures all incorporate diamond-shaped pores [Figure c]. The coordinated DMF/DEF solvent molecules occupy the space within the channels, thereby eliminating any porosity in these solvated species.

Extended Structures

When linked by the aryldicarboxylate anions, the linear cationic building blocks of 3-14 align parallel to one of the crystallographic axes (Tables  and ) to create similar 3D architectures (Figure ). With the exception of 8, which has triangular channels [Figure b], the extended structures all incorporate diamond-shaped pores [Figure c]. The coordinated DMF/DEF solvent molecules occupy the space within the channels, thereby eliminating any porosity in these solvated species.

elements.content: Complexes 5–7 and 10–14 all exhibit diamond-shaped channels and adopt similar space groups (Pnma or P212121). It is pertinent to note that it is compounds of the four longer anions, NDC2−, TPDC2−, PDC2−, and DADC2− but not those of the shortest anion, BDC2−, which adopt these particular structures with diamond-shaped channels. From simplistic calculations, using cell dimensions as a basis, of (i) cross-sectional area, (ii) volume per metal node, and (iii) depth (chain length) of the diamond-shaped channels in 5–7 and 10–14 [Table ; Figure c], it is possible to identify a number of trends influenced by metal node, bridging anion, and coordinated solvent. First, the chain length (Figure ) per metal node increases slightly from Ca2+ (3.435–3.477 Å) through Sr2+ (3.573–3.787 Å) to Ba2+ (4.039 Å) but is independent of anion and solvent. Second, the cross-sectional area of the channels (Figure ) increases from NDC2− through DADC2− to TPDC2−/PDC2− for a given metal node; similar trends are observed for the volume per metal node. This corresponds with an increase in the number of aromatic six-membered rings (2 → 3 → 4) in the carboxylate anion rather than an increase in its length (8.02 → 10.42 → 10.05 Å). Finally, DMF is incorporated in those structures containing the less laterally bulky anions (NDC2− and DADC2−), while DEF is incorporated in those structures containing the bulkier anions (TPDC2− and PDC2−). Within the Pnma and P212121 space groups, the bridging anions pack in a herringbone fashion with a translation of ±1 along the a axis and of ±0.5 along the b (Pnma) or c (P212121) axes (Figure ). Since the dimension of the a axis is rigidly controlled by the metal carboxylate interactions (6.874 ≤ a/Å ≤ 8.077 Å), change in the size (bulk and length) of the anion is thus necessarily accommodated by changes in the dimensions of the diamond-shaped channels.

elements.content: The 3D structure of 1 and 2 has a tilted α-Po type architecture. Two NDC2− anions link the trinuclear magnesium building blocks in the planes parallel to (100) to form 44 grids [Figure a]. The grids are stacked and linked through a third anion, by a (0.5, 0, 0.5) translation (Figure ) thereby allowing the terminal Mg2+ centers and their associated solvent molecules to interdigitate in the space available in the adjacent 44 grids. Thus, the building blocks are six-connecting units as required to generate the tilted α-Po type structure. The solvent molecules are located in channels aligned parallel to the a axis at (x, 0, 0.25), (x, 0.5, 0.25), (x, 0, 0.75), and (x, 0.5, 0.75). To accommodate the larger DEF solvent molecules in 1, the structure is expanded along the a axis by 14.3%; the other two cell dimensions differ by less than 1%.

elements.content: Fourteen metal−organic frameworks have been successfully crystallized from dialkylformamide solvents using a variety of Group II metal cations and diverse aryldicarboxylate anions. Detailed crystallographic analysis of the products has shown that eleven of them (3–7, 9–14) have similar framework topologies. To maintain the common structural type, the coordinated carboxylate moieties and solvent molecules adapt their coordination mode to the coordination number of the metal cation. Thus, to satisfy increasing coordination numbers from six for Mg2+ through seven for Ca2+ to eight for Sr2+ and Ba2+, each carboxylate oxygen binds to a greater number of metal centers and the solvent oxygen increasingly acts as a bridge. Of these 11 frameworks, extra solvent (H2O) was incorporated in the structure in only one case, 9. The frameworks comprise parallel chains of metal centers bridged by anions to produce diamond-shaped channels. Of these, eight (5–7, 10–14) adopt very similar structures with either Pnma or P212121 space groups within which trends influenced by the metal node, bridging anion, and coordinated solvent can be identified. The chain length (Figure ) per metal mode increases slightly with cation size but is independent of anion and solvent. The cross-sectional area of the channels and volume per metal node (Figure ) increases with an increase in the number of aromatic six-membered rings in the anion rather than an increase in its length. Solvent incorporation is dependent on the anion, DMF being included in structures containing the less bulky anions and DEF in structures containing the bulkier anions.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Fourteen metal-organic frameworks have been successfully crystallized from dialkylformamide solvents using a variety of Group II metal cations and diverse aryldicarboxylate anions. Detailed crystallographic analysis of the products has shown that eleven of them (3-7, 9-14) have similar framework topologies. To maintain the common structural type, the coordinated carboxylate moieties and solvent molecules adapt their coordination mode to the coordination number of the metal cation. Thus, to satisfy increasing coordination numbers from six for Mg2+ through seven for Ca2+ to eight for Sr2+ and Ba2+, each carboxylate oxygen binds to a greater number of metal centers and the solvent oxygen increasingly acts as a bridge. Of these 11 frameworks, extra solvent (H2O) was incorporated in the structure in only one case, 9. The frameworks comprise parallel chains of metal centers bridged by anions to produce diamond-shaped channels. Of these, eight (5-7, 10-14) adopt very similar structures with either Pnma or P212121 space groups within which trends influenced by the metal node, bridging anion, and coordinated solvent can be identified. The chain length (Figure ) per metal mode increases slightly with cation size but is independent of anion and solvent. The cross-sectional area of the channels and volume per metal node (Figure ) increases with an increase in the number of aromatic six-membered rings in the anion rather than an increase in its length. Solvent incorporation is dependent on the anion, DMF being included in structures containing the less bulky anions and DEF in structures containing the bulkier anions.

elements.content: Of the other three frameworks, 8 is based on parallel chains of metal centers bridged by anions, but in this case, the architecture has an hexagonal motif. The final two frameworks, those of 1 and 2, which are isomorphous, are quite different as the cationic building block is a trinuclear Mg2+ species. These act as six-connecting centers and are connected by NDC2− anions to give a tilted α-Po type structure.

The final two frameworks, those of 1 and 2, which are isomorphous, are quite different as the cationic building block is a trinuclear Mg2+ species. These act as six-connecting centers and are connected by NDC2- anions to give a tilted α-Po type structure.

elements.content: In compounds 3–14, the space within the channels is occupied by coordinated solvent molecules leading to a nonporous material. Thermal treatment not only removes coordinated solvent but can also result in a degree of loss of structural integrity, the details of which are currently under investigation. This is further complicated by isolated bulk materials not always being single phase and comprising mixtures of compounds. Despite this, we are encouraged by the consistent formation of material-incorporating channels and are currently investigating alternative, less-symmetrical bridging ligands, and alternative solvents and conditions for the construction of main group framework complexes.

Thermal treatment not only removes coordinated solvent but can also result in a degree of loss of structural integrity, the details of which are currently under investigation. This is further complicated by isolated bulk materials not always being single phase and comprising mixtures of compounds. Despite this, we are encouraged by the consistent formation of material-incorporating channels and are currently investigating alternative, less-symmetrical bridging ligands, and alternative solvents and conditions for the construction of main group framework complexes.
